1.words: Welcome to this special community celebration conversation, hosted by Cortico's Local Voice Network, and United Way of Dane County. Thanks for agreeing to participate in this conversation, and I have begun recording. I'm just going to go over some things, just some key ground rules. Just to speak for yourself, and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Stay curious, pause, listen generously, and also stay present. I just want to make sure everyone's onboard with these guidelines, we just shared in the large group, and if there's anything you would like to add or change. Okay, perfect. Now we'll move on to some introductory questions, and to make this conversation a little bit easier, in the beginning, we'll use a modified circle. So we'll start with Jessie, Amy, and then go to Martinez. Please tell me if I got your names right. I'm ... Okay, perfect. We'll just use this modified circle to make things run more smoothly. I also want to mention, you can always pass, and we can come back to you, or if you just don't want to answer that question, you don't have to. Feel no obligation there. We're just going to do a quick round of introductions. So, we're just going to ask if you would share your first name, your gender pronouns if you're comfortable doing so, and also, in addition, just share a little bit of background info about who you are and a value that's important to you. I'll go first. My name's Anna. My pronouns are she, her, hers. A value that's important to me is honesty. I really value people being honest and wanting to share their ... Just what they think. I think it just makes it a lot easier and a lot better. This value relates to the community and why I'm here today, because where would I be if people weren't honest? I feel like you can only get so far, and if people aren't truthful, then you're just being held back in the past, and you're not really present, in the moment. With that, I 'll pass it to Jessie.

2.words: Hi, everybody. My name is Jessie. My pronouns are she, her. A little bit about myself, I'm a nurse. I'm born and raised in Madison, although I've lived some other places. I ended up coming right on back here, so ... I love Madison, and I love it so much, that I want to see it fulfill its potential. I would say that, a value that's important to me is, the idea of constant growth. I think that, that includes accepting mistakes that you've made in the past as growth, in addition to looking to the future and accepting the way that you are, as constantly transitioning.

3.words: Thank you. Then we'll move on to Amy.

4.words: Good morning. I'm Amy [Surname]. I was in Madison as a teacher for 23 years, and I just shifted to Sun Prairie. I'm an instructional coach at an elementary school in Sun Prairie. Something ... Jessie, I also want to help see Madison find its potential. We are so far from it, we have a lot of work yet to do but, it's great to know that there's other people who know that there's a lot of promise in our children, and our families, and beyond. My pronouns are she, hers. I would say that a value that I really hold true is, I really appreciate persistence and perseverance. Things are hard and we need to go through that productive struggle. I think Jessie spoke to making mistakes, and I just taught a group of fourth graders this morning, that making mistakes literally creates new patterns in our brains. They grow our brains, and so, yep, we're going to screw up along the way, and that's okay, as long as we get back up and try again. I'm grateful to be here. I will do my best to be fully present, that's my commitment, to do my best.

6.words: Good afternoon, everyone. I'm Martinez. I'm excited to be here. I'm a newly installed development director here, at the United Way of Dane County, so I'm excited in my role. I wanted to be a part of today's conversation to understand new perspectives, and I think that's something that is one of my biggest values, is open mindedness. It's been said here in many different ways, having a growth mindset, and being open to new ideas, and being able to empathize with other people, even though you might not have that same lived experience. That's something that I hold true to my heart, as a value, and as a moral of mine. My pronouns are he and him, and I'm excited to be here, so let's keep the conversation going.

14.words: Yeah, that's most accurate. It's more like the center of a wheelhouse, where all of the different spokes come in to a center piece and a nucleus. United way is that nucleus, for us to make sure that we can get the funds dispersed in an equitable fashion, but also in a way where we're going to be able to find measurable results. So we're looking at the root causes of some of the challenges we see in our communities, and what we can do to get to the bedrock of some of the issues, so we can solve them over the course of time. Not immediately, but over the course of years and generations, to make sure we have intergenerational impact.

21.words: I grew up outside Chicago, so I appreciate how Dane County allows me to be my city mouse, country mouse. I can feel like I can seamlessly go between Madison proper and into rural areas, to explore the out of doors. I think the reason that I stuck around here, is because, I think, the families. I love the families, many of whom have come up from Chicago. There's just something about the families here that I love, and the children.

22.words: I like the resourcefulness of Madison. I'm originally from Milwaukee, but I've lived half my life here, in Madison. I went to college here, as early as 16 years old, so at 31 years old, my life has been installed and been built here, in the Dane County community. I just think that it's a place where you can really put some roots down and build something monumental. There are a lot of good resources, and a lot of good organizations that are working to change the image of our state, and also our national impact, as a participant in national politics, national education development, things of that sort. So I appreciate everything being here, that gives us the opportunity to build exponentially, and not in a slow fashion.

29.words: I love that. I would say, what I love about Dane County, partly, it's the green. Just because a lot of times when I'm ... One of the things that I noticed when I moved away ... I fled Madison and Wisconsin, and when I came back, I really was struck by how beautiful all the trees are. Do you know what I mean? That I never really appreciated before. I was like, "Whoa." And also, I think, kind of piggybacking on some of what was already said, I think that Madison does have a willingness to be different, that I think is commendable. It's not ... I don't think that always, Madison achieves that, or Dane County achieves that, and maybe not as much as we think, but I think there is a willingness to be innovative and to be like, we're not like any other place. And I think that is a strength.

31.words: In the recent past, I worked with a group of students who went on a college tour, about a year or so back, and it was a group of students who emerged from an underprivileged environment, who got a chance to see ... Through a local church here in Madison, who got a chance to see what college looks like at a HBCU, or Historically Black College or University. For me, I thought that, that was really unique, in the sense that these students are getting a chance to see what their future could look like now. One of the guys actually moved on to do some acting work, and he's been featured on a couple national TV shows. So I thought it was really cool to build his desire for acting, through education. Then him go on to go to college, and then to start, early on in college, already embarking on an acting career. And it all started from some local work that was done here, and the community people, who wanted to see Black kids have access to Black, higher education. That's important to me, and I think education has been a theme here, and it's one of our items on the agenda for change. So I think that, that's really dynamic that kids get a chance to see something bigger and better, and then get a chance to manifest their destiny in those different realms.

32.words: Yeah, Martinez. I would piggyback on that. 35.words: Let's see. I would say that, more recently now, as I am older, I think that I have recognized that things don't always have to be the way they seem. I remember a local leader said something that really stood out to me about ... I was talking to some friends about this, this is why this stands out in my mind. About the idea that women don't get along, or don't support each other, or stick together. I think that, for some people, that really resonates. But she said, "I hear that, and that just really hasn't been my experience." I just remember, as a young person taking in these kinds of ideas that Black girls and Black women, we don't stick together, we don't, whatever. But as I have talked to my friend group from high school, that we're still tight, we're even tighter since COVID, we talked about this. We talked about this story, and realized that, that's kind of been the same for us. That hasn't really been our experience. 69.words: Here's what I would share. I have this unique experience. I intentionally left Madison schools after 23 years, where I just loved the children and loved what I did. I was given an opportunity to move to Sun Prairie, and I feel like I've gotten a new leash on life. But I no longer have the diversity that Madison afforded me, so I've lost that. But interestingly, I feel like I've gained a staff that has tremendous willingness for growth. A growth mindset to learn, and eager to want to be the change. Even though at our school, it's the, who we create when they leave our walls, that we aspire to. Because we just ... Our diversity is we have 20 children who identify as Black in this building, and that may be multi-racial Black, as African-American being one of the indicators. So we aspire to create strong individuals, as they leave our system, who are those global citizens. I don't know that, that same growth mindset was pervasive in Madison. I feel like ... And that's my experience, and the schools where I experienced. There were some schools that I have been touched by, as somebody whose been out of the classroom supporting schools, that have growth mindset. But some ... I was just ... I'm blown away by the growth mindset out here in the suburbs, I have to tell you. That's kind of what I'm saying. There's promise, and I just don't know why I was faced with something like a fixed mindset, like an entitlement, I guess, in MSD. By some.

74.words: As a community member, and I think as someone that's been transient and has kind of built, over the course of time, my livelihood in Madison, I think I realized that, there are a lot of students who are part of the pipeline programs at the university level, at the collegiate level, who are first gen, who are still experiencing this bastardization of their part of the state. So if you come from Milwaukee, or you come from Racine, Kenosha, Southeastern Wisconsin, and you come to Madison as a PEOPLE program scholar, or even as a POSSE scholar from LA, from Chicago, from DC, from all these other places, you come here ... I think there's a lack of engagement beyond the campus environment, for people to get acclimated to the city, and to the community, so they see it as a viable option when they graduate. That's kind of a little bit of brain drain, that I see here in Madison, when it comes to, specifically young, Black professionals, and young millennials of color, who are all different races and backgrounds, but who just don't feel the vibe, and don't feel the connection to the city, beyond the campus. So I think that's the area of opportunity at the higher level, at the higher education level, because we're getting all of these multi-talented students from around the world coming here, and then they leave here.

So they won't think about jumping straight to Chicago. there's a lot of work to be done in that space, so we could keep the smart people here too.

I don't know if Jessie has any experience with that, or if you went to school in Madison or something like that?

I don't think about the surrounding parts of Madison, so it's crazy to think ... It was kind of ... When I learned that Dane County included these different areas, I was like, "Really? Are you sure?" So, it's funny that there's this whole life within Dane County that most students don't know about. I don't know if Jessie has any experience with that, or if you went to school in Madison or something like that?
75.linked_words: Aren't you in a position ... I love that. I think about a guy I grew up with who came to Madison. He has no idea where off campus is. He's never left campus. What? How are you not going to leave campus? Campus is stupid. No offense. Campus ... There's so much more in Madison. There's neighborhoods and people, and homes and schools. Can United Way serve as that spoke?

78.words: Like I said, I left Madison as fast I could, when I graduated from high school, to go to an HBCU. Even though I ended up ... I graduated from UW-Madison. Eventually, I came home and finished school here but ... It's hard. I don't necessarily have the perspective of ever thinking of Dane County as only the campus because honestly, partly because I was an adult student when I was at UW-Madison. So I didn't have those 18, 19, 20, early 20s experiences that so many UW-Madison students have. I didn't ever really think of myself as part of that kind of student community, but I definitely could see ... I think that for Black professionals and really any professionals of color to want to stay in Madison, I feel like they need to see themselves represented to a greater degree. I think that our communities of color seem to be hidden, to people who come to Madison looking for community and some place where people look like them, speak their language and check their food. You know what I'm saying? I think it's like, you have to have an inside tract to be able to find ... And I just think that thought really carries through, as far as, even the communities who are native to Madison, who are communities of color, feeling a part of the infrastructure. It feels like inclusion to somebody else's structure and system. I think that's part of the problem, and .... I don't know. As far as I know, it's been like that. It's like we have our own, but it's not really a part of where the power in Madison resides.

74.linked_words: As a community member, and I think as someone that's been transient and has kind of built, over the course of time, my livelihood in Madison, I think I realized that, there are a lot of students who are part of the pipeline programs at the university level, at the collegiate level, who are first gen, who are still experiencing this bastardization of their part of the state. So if you come from Milwaukee, or you come from Racine, Kenosha, Southeastern Wisconsin, and you come to Madison as a PEOPLE program scholar, or even as a POSSE scholar from LA, from Chicago, from DC, from all these other places, you come here ... I think there's a lack of engagement beyond the campus environment, for people to get acclimated to the city, and to the community, so they see it as a viable option when they graduate. That's kind of a little bit of brain drain, that I see here in Madison, when it comes to, specifically young, Black professionals, and young millennials of color, who are all different races and backgrounds, but who just don't feel the vibe, and don't feel the connection to the city, beyond the campus. So I think that's the area of opportunity at the higher level, at the higher education level, because we're getting all of these multi-talented students from around the world coming here, and then they leave here.

81.words: One of those opening quotes was something about the fabric of Madison. We need ... The fabric of Madison is not yet in the favor of the non-dominant culture, the White culture, so we need to shift that. Right? I also need to get off my conscience, I'm sorry I called campus stupid. Mainly what I'm trying to say is, Madison, there's so much good in this city, and the reason that I stuck around is because I got to know the kids and their families, and I wasn't going to leave. So as you're speaking, Martinez, I got to know community, and when I got to know community, I felt compelled to stick around, and not return home to Chicago. But I did that through volunteering, and then I did that through gainful, after school employment. So I appreciate your thinking through how to get people to stick around, especially so that people do see Black and Brown faces as leaders and viable community members, doing what our city needs, which is just good work. One of the things that you said, Jessie, at the beginning, was the idea of root causes stuck with you, when Anna prompted us. And then, in your next sharing, you shared that you fled. So, at some point, it'd be interesting to unpack what root causes pushed you to ... It sounds like you fled, like you got on out of here. Right? But then, here you are. So what next, for us? Not for you, for us.

83.words: I grew up on the West side. This is the West side, East side thing too, because I grew up on the West side, but I really love ... I live on the North side now, I love it. I love it. I don't know. I think that, kind of how I talked about in my story, about the whole mindset and the reality that is created for you or presented to you, as a young person in Madison, is the limit. There's so many limits, there's so many boundaries, and there's so much that you are told that you can be and can not be, and these are your options, rather than really, that your options are limitless, and that you're in control. I think that, just like with parenting, it's like, I can tell you, this is an equitable society here, and we're all equal or whatever. But, I think that kids learn in practice and through their eyes that, that's not true. I just think that ... I knew that something wasn't right, and I just wanted to be in a place where it wasn't ... That I wasn't the only Black person in a space, or that there's the Black table. I never ... I think I had one Black instructor throughout my whole educational experience, until I went away to college.

88.words: I work on a committee, Downtown Madison Inc. has a committee, the Business Improvement District, where we're looking at the future of downtown Madison. What it needs to be, to be enjoyable by different, inclusive communities. Some of the ... We're doing a big landscape approach to ... Just a new vision. What id could really be, if it was perfect. If it was utopian downtown Madison, what it would look like. Some of the things that have come up, from just within the in group, is places where young professionals of color, where they typically congregate. We need different types of food venues downtown. We need different areas where Black women and young Black men can get their hair cut, or get it done at a salon. We need those comfortable spaces that normally exist within metropolitan, of Black folks and young people of color, where you might see in Chicago or Atlanta, Dallas, things of that sort, but not just here. It's just not here in Madison. So some of those small things, some of those cultural things, because culture is a meaning and people together. If we have all these people and they don't have a common understanding, there can be no culture, so we're looking to create a culture and craft a new vision for what it means to be a part of this community, and be a young person of color. Do you have the things downtown that signify, and are sign posts, for you to be comfortable in that environment? If you see a country club, you might think of a certain profile of a person that's going to be comfortable in that space, versus seeing a youth center or a skating rink, and some Black restaurant food nearby. So we have to create those spaces for people to coexist, and build, and feel safe. It happens in other parts of the country, it's just not happening here, just yet. But we're on the precipice of change right now. So yeah, I'm excited. I'm definitely excited for folks like Jessie to be back in this environment, for innovative thinkers like Amy, who's been around for a while, to think about how we can make this even better.

We need those comfortable spaces that normally exist within metropolitan, of Black folks and young people of color, where you might see in Chicago or Atlanta, Dallas, things of that sort, but not just here. It's just not here in Madison. So some of those small things, some of those cultural things, because culture is a meaning and people together. If we have all these people and they don't have a common understanding, there can be no culture, so we're looking to create a culture and craft a new vision for what it means to be a part of this community, and be a young person of color. Do you have the things downtown that signify, and are sign posts, for you to be comfortable in that environment? If you see a country club, you might think of a certain profile of a person that's going to be comfortable in that space, versus seeing a youth center or a skating rink, and some Black restaurant food nearby. So we have to create those spaces for people to coexist, and build, and feel safe. It happens in other parts of the country, it's just not happening here, just yet. But we're on the precipice of change right now. So yeah, I'm excited. I'm definitely excited for folks like Jessie to be back in this environment, for innovative thinkers like Amy, who's been around for a while, to think about how we can make this even better.
